content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The population of a virus in a host can be modeled by the function <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of A, with respect to t, equals t minus, one fifth A"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in millions of virus cells and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in days for <math alttext="5 less than or equal to t, less than 10"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days, there are 10 million cells of the virus in the host. (a) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the tangent line to approximate the number of virus cells in the host, in millions, at time <math alttext="t equals 7"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The population of a virus in a host can be modeled by the function <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of A, with respect to t, equals t minus, one fifth A"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in millions of virus cells and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in days for <math alttext="5 less than or equal to t, less than 10"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days, there are 10 million cells of the virus in the host. (a) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the tangent line to approximate the number of virus cells in the host, in millions, at time <math alttext="t equals 7"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days.

(b) Show that <math alttext="A of t, equals, negative 25 plus 5 t, plus 10 times e raised to the negative of the fraction t over 5, end fraction, plus 1, power"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>25</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of A, with respect to t, equals t minus, one fifth A"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="A of 5, equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) The host receives an antiviral medication. The amount of medication in the host is modeled by the function <math alttext="M"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of M, with respect to t, equals negative one half, times open parenthesis, the fraction with numerator M, and denominator t plus k, end fraction, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="M"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in milligrams, <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in days since the host received the medication, and <math alttext="k"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a positive constant. If the amount of medication in the host is 30 milligrams at time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days and 15 milligrams at time <math alttext="t equals 3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days, what is <math alttext="M of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
